title: Harry Dunn: US diplomat's wife does not have diplomatic immunity
text:
Anna Sacoolas’ lawyers have agreed to meet with a spokesperson for Harry Dunn’s family (Picture: Facebook/PA)

The parents of a teenager killed in a crash have been told the suspect, a US official’s wife, does not have diplomatic immunity.

Harry, 19, was killed after his motorbike collided with a car outside an RAF base on August 27.

Anna Sacoolas, 42, who is reportedly married to a US diplomat, is suspected of allegedly driving down the wrong side of the road when the vehicles crashed.

She returned to the US after she was granted diplomatic immunity, and Harry’s heartbroken parents, Charlotte Charles and Tim Dunn, have been calling on witnesses to come forward.

However, Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab has now said Ms Sacoolas does not have immunity and the investigation has been put in the hands of Northamptonshire Police.

The letter reads: ‘The question remains when such immunity comes to an end, regardless of any waiver.

Harry, 19, was killed in a crash (Picture: Instagram)

‘We have looked at this very carefully, as I wanted to be confident in the position before conveying it to you.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘The UK government’s position is that immunity, and therefore any question of waiver, is no longer relevant in Mrs Sacoolas’ case, because she has returned home.

‘The US have now informed us that they too consider that immunity is no longer pertinent.

‘In these circumstances, Harry’s case is now a matter for Northants police and the CPS to take forward.

‘That of course is done entirely independently, and it would not be right for me to comment any further.’

The news comes after Ms Sacoolas’ lawyer contacted the Dunn family earlier to say their client wanted to meet Harry’s parents to ‘express her deepest sympathies and apologies’.

Her statement read: ‘Anne is devastated by this tragic accident. No loss compares to the death of a child and Anne extends her deepest sympathy to Harry Dunn’s family.

Charlotte Charles and her partner said they haven’t been able to grieve for their son’s death ahead of the US visit (Picture: PA)

‘The media reporting has been inaccurate in many respects. To begin with, Anne fully cooperated with the police and the investigation.

‘She spoke with authorities at the scene of the accident and met with the Northampton police at her home the following day. She will continue to cooperate with the investigation.

‘Anne would like to meet with Mr Dunn’s parents so that she can express her deepest sympathies and apologies for this tragic accident.

‘We have been in contact with the family’s attorneys and look forward to hearing from them.’

Advertisement

Parents Charlotte and Tim, who said they haven’t been able to grieve over their son’s death, had flown to the US to put pressure on officials to ‘do the right thing’.

Earlier on Saturday, their spokesman appealed for witnesses to come forward if they had seen Ms Sacoolas leaving the UK.

Boris Johnson said on Friday that the US had been ‘absolutely ruthless’ in its safeguarding of Ms Sacoolas after granting her immunity.

Charlotte Charles with son Harry (Picture: PA)

The PM said although President Trump was sympathetic towards Harry’s family’s views on the use of diplomatic immunity, the US were ‘very reluctant’ to allow citizens to be tried abroad.

Following an earlier phone call with the British PM, Mr Trump called the crash a ‘terrible accident’ but defended Ms Sacoolas saying it was easy to drive on the wrong side of the road.

Speaking ahead of their campaign in the US, Harry’s family said in a statement that they ‘continue to live in a nightmare’.

A statement released on behalf of the family said: ‘As if losing Harry was not enough, they now find themselves having to expend enormous time and energy, which they can ill afford, generating sufficient publicity to garner public support to persuade the US government to help achieve closure and return the driver Mrs Sacoolas to England to face the consequences of her actions.

Harry’s parents said they have been ‘living in a nightmare’ (Picture: PA)

‘Sadly, all such efforts to date have failed. The parents, after a brief period of rest, are therefore now taking their campaign to the USA and will visit New York City and Washington DC over the coming days, engaging with the media and politicians as they reach out for support from all Americans and to ask them to put pressure on the US administration to do the right thing.

Advertisement

‘They are looking forward to making as many new friends in the USA as possible.

‘Harry’s family will simply not leave matters where they are and will do whatever it takes, including taking legal action if necessary, to secure Justice 4 Harry.’

description: Lawyer of US diplomat's wife Anna Sacoolas has agreed to meet the spokesperson for Harry Dunn's family.
